123.1: GEMARA: Ravina said in the name of Rava: "Learn from the words of Rabbi Yehudah that the mitzvah to place [Chanukkah candles] is within ten [tefachim, hand-breadths]. That if you would have thought that [the mitzvah] was for above ten [hand-breadths] why would Rabbi Yehudah [maintain that the one who places a] Chanukkah candle [that does damage] is exempt? Why should [the plaintiff] not say [against] him "You should place it above the camel and it's rider!" Rather, no. Learn from this that the mitzvah is to place it within ten. 47.43: We studied in the Mishnah: How is the penalty assessed for an ox that damages while on the private domain of the damaged party?
47.44: If the ox gores, pushes, bites, crouches, [or] kicks (all these are later classified as similar to "horn", i.e., damage caused through unusual behavior) -- in the public domain, he [the owner] pays full damages. In the domain of the damaged party, Rabbi Tarfon says [the owner pays]
47.45: full damages, while The Sages say,
47.47: Rabbi Tarfon said to them [using a fortiori reasoning]
47.48: in a case where we are lenient with respect to "tooth" and "leg" [damages caused by normal behavior] in the public domain, where he [the owner] is completely exempt, we are strict regarding the private domain of the damaged party, [requiring the owner] to pay full damages. In a case where we are strict with "horn" damage [damage from unusual behavior, as described above] in the public domain, [requiring the owner] to pay half-damages, isn't it logical [a fortiori] that we should be strict with him in the domain of the injured party to pay full damages?
47.49: hey [The Sages] said to him [R Tarfon],
47.50: it is enough that a law derived from an a fortiori argument be established similar to the case from which the inference is drawn [i.e., the derived principle cannot be more strict than the base case]. Just as in the public domain [the payment for "horn" damage is] half-damages, so too in the domain of the damaged party [the payment for "horn" damage is] half-damage.
47.51: He [R Tarfon] said to them [The Sages],

48.0: will not derive "horn" [damage] from "horn" damage, I will derive "horn" damage from "leg" damage.
48.1: In a case where we are lenient with respect to "tooth" and "leg" [damages caused by normal behavior] in the public domain [where the owner is exempt], we are strict with regard to "horn" damage [where the owner pays half-damages]. [By a fortiori reasoning] in the case where we are strict with regard to "tooth" and "leg", [namely] in the domain of the damaged party, isn't it logical that we should be strict[er] with regard to "horn" [and require payment of full damages]?
48.2: They [The Sages] said to him [R Tarfon],
48.3: it is enough that a law derived from an a fortiori argument be established similar to the case from which the inference is drawn.
48.4: Just as in the public domain [the payment for "horn" damage is] half-damages, so too in the domain of the damaged party [the payment for "horn" damage is] half-damage.

58.44: "At the time of taking out [foilage to become] fertilizer, people take out their fertilizer to the public domain and heaps it all there for thirty days so that it will be trampled upon by the feet of people and the feet of animals. And it was due to this condition that Joshua caused [Israel] to inherit the land.
58.45: Even if you say [the mishnah accords] with Rabbi Yehudah, for Rabbi Yehudah agrees that if damage was caused [the owner of the fertilizer] should compensate for the damage,
58.46: but there is a teaching that Rabbi Yehudah said:
58.47: "In regards to a Chanukkah candle, he is exempt because he had permission [to place it in the public domain].
58.48: Is it not the case that this permission comes from the courthouse?
58.49: No, but the permission comes from the mitzvah,
58.51: 'in regards to a Chanukkah candle, he is exempt because he had permission [to place it in the public domain] of a mitzvah.
58.53: In all the cases where they said that it is permissible to [place] nuisances in the public domain, if they caused damages they [the one who placed the nuisances] are obligated to compensate, and Rabbi Yehudah exempts them.
58.55: "Our Mishnah is not during the time of taking out [foilage to become] fertilizer, and it is Rabbi Yehudah [who wrote it].

59.0: "His straw and his thatch" [The mishnah] teaches because they are slippery.

60.3: We learned in the Mishnah: [In the case of] two potters who were walking one behind the other, and the first tripped and fell, and the second tripped on the first, the first [potter] is liable for the damage to the second [potter].

61.30: We learned in the Mishnah: One came with his barrel and one came with his beam. [If] this one's jug were broken on this one's beam, [the beam's owner] is exempt, because this one has permission to walk and this one [also] has permission to walk.
61.31: If the beam's owner was in front, and the barrel's owner was behind, [then] if the barrel broke on the beam, the beam's owner is exempt.

62.0: [But] if the beam's owner stopped, he is liable. [But] if he said to the barrel's owner, "Stop,"
62.2: If the barrel's owner was in front, and the beam's owner was behind, [then] if the barrel broke on the beam, then he is liable. [But] if the barrel's owner stopped, he is exempt.
62.3: [But] if he said to the beam's owner, "Stop," he is liable.
62.35: We learned in the Mishnah: [In the case where] two people were traveling in the public domain, one running and the other walking, or if both were running, and they damaged each other, both are exempt....
62.36: The Mishnah does not accord with Issi ben Yehudah
62.37: As it was taught: Issi ben Yehudah says
62.38: One who runs is liable because he acts differently
62.39: And Issi agrees on Friday eve at twilight that he is exempt for he runs with permission.
62.4: So too [the case of] one who comes with his candle and one with his flax.
62.40: R. Yohanan said: Halakhah is according to Issi ben Yehudah.
62.58: What permission is there on Friday eve?

63.0: Come and go out to greet the bride, the queen
63.2: To greet the Sabbath, the bride, the queen.
63.3: R. Yannai would cover himself and say
63.5: We learned in the Mishnah: [If] one was splitting [wood] in a private domain and [thereby] caused damage in the public domain, or [split wood] in the public domain and caused damage in a private domain, or [split wood] in a private domain and caused damaged in a different private domain, he is liable.

64.24: We learned in the Mishnah: [If] two oxen that are categorized as "tam" (meaning that they have not proven themselves "muad", or prone to causing injury) injured each other, they pay half-damages of the excess (i.e., the damages to one are subtracted from the damages to the other, the difference is calculated, and the owner of the ox that caused the greater damage pays half the difference).
64.25: [If] both [oxen] are categorized as "muad" (prone to causing damage), they pay full damages of the excess. ...
64.26: [In the case where] one [ox] is a "tam" and one is a "muad": [If] the "muad" injures the "tam", its owner pays full damages of the excess.
64.27: [If] the "tam" injures the "muad", its owner pays half-damages of the excess.
64.28: And similarly, [in the case of] two men who injured each other, they pay full damages of the excess. ...
64.29: [If] a man injured a "muad" [ox] and the "muad" injured the man, they pay full damages of the excess. ...
64.30: [If] a man injured a "tam" [ox] and the "tam" injured the man: [If the injury caused by the] man to the "tam" [is greater] then he pays full damages of the excess. [If the injury caused by the] "tam" to the man [is greater] then he [the owner of the ox] pays half-damages of the excess. ...
64.32: even [in the case where the injury caused by the] "tam" to the man [is greater], he [the owner of the ox] pays full damages of the excess....
64.46: We learned in the Mishnah: [Regarding the case of ] an ox worth a maneh (100 zuz) that gored an ox worth 200 [zuz] and the carcass is worthless, he [the owner of the dead ox] takes the [live] ox.

66.34: We learned in the Mishnah: [Regarding the case of ] an ox worth a 200 [zuz] that gored an ox worth 200 [zuz] and the carcass is worthless: Rabbi Meir says,
66.35: this is the case referred to by the verse (Exodus 21), "And they shall sell the live ox and divide its worth."
66.37: "And is this truly the law?" You have fulfilled [the verse], "And they shall sell the live ox and divide its worth," but you have not fulfilled [the continuation of the verse] "And they shall also divide the dead [ox]." How is this?
66.38: This refers to [the case of] an ox worth a 200 [zuz] that gored an ox worth 200 [zuz] and the carcass is worth 50 zuz, that this one takes half the value of the live [ox] and half the value of the dead [ox], and this one takes half the value of the live [ox] and half the value of the dead [ox].

67.36: We learned in the Mishnah: There is [a case] where one is liable for the action of his ox, but exempt from his own action, [and a case] where he is exempt for the action of his ox, but liable for his own action.
67.38: [If] his ox embarrassed [another person], he is exempt. [But if] he embarrassed [another person], he is liable. ...
67.39: [If] his ox blinded the eye of his slave or knocked out his tooth, he is exempt. [But if] he blinded the eye of his slave or knocked out his tooth, he is liable.
67.40: [If] his ox injured his father or mother, he is liable. [But if] he injured his father or mother, he is exempt (from monetary damages).
67.41: [If] his ox lit a pile of grain on the Sabbath, he is liable. [But if] he lit a pile of grain on the Sabbath, he is exempt (from monetary damages). [In the last 2 cases, he is exempt from monetary damages] because he is liable for capital punishment.

68.28: We learned in the Mishnah: [If] an ox was chasing after another ox, and caused damage. This one says
68.29: "Your ox damaged," and this one says,
68.30: "No, your ox was injured on a rock," the burden of proof is upon the one who wishes to be compensated. ...
68.31: If two [oxen] were chasing after one [ox], this one says, ...
68.32: "Your ox damaged," and this one says,...

69.1: If both [oxen] belonged to a single owner, both are liable.
69.10: "No, the small one injured the large one and the large one injured the small one"
69.11: [Or if] one was a "tam" and one was a "muad," and the injured [owner] says, ...
69.12: "The 'muad' damaged the large one and the 'tam' damaged the small one," and the one who damaged says,
69.13: "No, the 'tam' injured the large one and the 'muad' injured the small one" [in these cases] the burden of proof is upon the one who wishes to be compensated.
69.2: If one was large and one was small, and the injured [owner] says,
69.3: "The large one damaged," and the one who damaged says,
69.5: [Or If] one was a "tam" (not observed to habitually inflict damage) and one was a "muad" (observed to habitually inflict damage), and the injured [owner] says,
69.7: "No, the 'tam' damaged"  [in these cases] the burden of proof is upon the one who wishes to be compensated.
69.8: If two [oxen] were damaged, one large and one small, and two [oxen] caused the damage, one large and one small. The injured [owner] says,
69.9: "The large one damaged the large one and the small one damaged the small one," and the one who damaged says, ...

70.24: We learned in the Mishnah: An ox which has gored four or five other oxen, this one after this one: he shall pay to [the owner of] the last ox injured. If there remains, it will go to the [the owner of] the previously [injured ox]. If there still remains, it will go to the [the owner of the ox injured] previous to the previously [injured ox]. [The owner of] the last [injured ox] benefits, the words of Rabbi Meir.
70.26: [If] an ox worth 200 gores an ox worth 200 and the carcass is not worth anything, this one gets 100 and this one gets 100. ...
70.27: [If] it goes back and injures another ox worth 200, the [owner of the] ox last injured receives 100 and the owner of the previously injured ox receives 50. ...
70.28: [If] it injures another ox worth 200, the [owner of the] ox last injured receives 100, the [owner of the] previously injured ox receives 50, and the first two receive 25.

72.10: “For [damages on] Sabbaths [its owner] pays full damages and for [damages] during the week [its owner] pays half damages.”
72.12: After it refrains from [damaging] for three Sabbath days.
72.6: We learned in the Mishnah: An ox which is warned for [injuring] its own species, and is not warned for [injuring] that which is not its own species; or is warned for [injuring] people and not warned for [injuring] animals; or is warned for [injuring] children and not warned for [injuring] adults—that for which it is warned [its owner] pays full damages, and that for which it is not warned [its owner] pays half damages.
72.7: They said in front of Rabbi Judah:
72.8: What if it is warned [for injuring] on the Sabbath, and it is not warned for during the week?”

73.22: We learned in the Mishnah: An ox of an Israelite that gored an ox belonging to the Temple, or an ox belonging to the Temple
73.23: that gored an ox of an Israelite, he is exempt, as it says, “The ox belonging to his neighbor” (Exodus 21:35), and not an ox belonging to the Temple. An ox of an Israelite that gores an ox of a non-Jew, he is exempt. And an ox of a non-Jew that gores the ox of an Israelite, whether the ox is harmless or an attested danger, its owner pays full damages.

76.10: “When it will gore” (Exodus 21:28), and not When others cause it to gore.
76.4: We learned in the Mishnah: [If] an ox of a person of sound senses gored the ox of a deaf-mute, a person lacking sound senses, or a minor, he is obligated. [If] an ox of a deaf-mute, a person lacking sound senses or a minor, gored the ox of a person of sound senses, he is exempt.
76.5: [If] an ox a deaf-mute, a person lacking sound senses or a minor gored, the court appoints a guardian over them, and they testified against them in the presence of the guardian.
76.6: [If] the deaf-mute regained his hearing, or the person lackign sound senses recovered his senses, or the minor came of age, [the ox] returns to being harmless, the words of Rabbi Meir.
76.9: An ox from the stadium is not liable to be put to death, as it says, ...

80.10: So too [if it killed] a son or a daughter. ...
80.11: If it gored a male slave or a female slave he pays 30 sela, whether [the slave] was worth a maneh or not even worth a dinar.
80.9: We learned in the Mishnah: An ox that gored a person and he died: If it was an attested danger [its owner] must pay the ransom, If it was harmless he is exempt from paying the ransom. In both cases the ox is obligated for the death penalty.

86.14: If an ox was rubbing against a wall and it fell on a person; or if it intended to kill an animal and it killed a man; or a non-Jew and it killed an Israelite; or an untimely birth and it killed a viable infant, it is exempt [from death].

87.33: We learned in the Mishnah: An ox of a woman, or the ox of orphans, or the ox of a guardian, or a wild ox, or an ox belonging to the Temple, or an ox belonging to a convert who died and has no inheritors, these are all liable for the death penalty.
87.35: A wild ox, or an ox belonging to the Temple, or an ox belonging to a convert who died are exempt from death, since they have no owners.
87.55: We learned in the Mishnah: If an ox is going out to be stoned, and its owners dedicated it to the Temple, it is not considered dedicated. If he slaughtered it, its flesh is forbidden.
87.56: But if before its sentence was complete its owner dedicated it, it is dedicated. And If he slaughtered it, its flesh is permitted
87.57: If he handed it to an unpaid guardian, or to a borrower, or to a paid guardian, or to a hirer, they take the place of the owners; an attested danger pays full damages, and a harmless ox pays half damages.

89.24: We learned in the Mishnah: If its owner had tied it with a halter, or locked it up properly, but it came out and caused damage, the owner is liable, whether it was an attested danger or accounted harmless, the words of Rabbi Meir.
89.26: A harmless ox is liable, but an attested danger is exempt, as it says,
89.27: “and its owner did not guard it”, and this one has been guarded. ...
89.29: It can only be guarded by the knife.

99.3: A person may not take stones from his domain into the public domain.
99.4: A story is told of a person who was clearing stones from his domain into the public domain, and a certain pious person found him. He said to him,
99.5: "Why are you clearing out a domain that does not belong to you into a domain that belongs to you?"
99.6: He scoffed at him. After a time that person had to sell his field, and he was walking in that public area, and he stumbled on one of the stones. He said,
99.7: "That pious person spoke well when he said to me , why are you clearing stones from a domain that is not yours to a domain that is yours."
